title: Eurovision Song Contest 2018
text:
The Eurovision Song Contest 2018 was the 63rd edition of the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a>. It took place in <a href="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>, following the country's victory at the with the song "<a href="Amar%20pelos%20dois">Amar pelos dois</a>" by <a href="Salvador%20Sobral">Salvador Sobral</a>. It was the first time Portugal had hosted the contest54 years after the country made its debut in .
Organised by the <a href="European%20Broadcasting%20Union">European Broadcasting Union</a> (EBU) and host broadcaster <a href="R%C3%A1dio%20e%20Televis%C3%A3o%20de%20Portugal">Rádio e Televisão de Portugal</a> (RTP), the contest was held at the <a href="Altice%20Arena">Altice Arena</a>, and consisted of two semi-finals on 8 and 10 May, and the final on 12 May 2018. The three live shows were presented by Portuguese television presenters <a href="Filomena%20Cautela">Filomena Cautela</a>, <a href="S%C3%ADlvia%20Alberto">Sílvia Alberto</a> and <a href="Catarina%20Furtado">Catarina Furtado</a> and American actress <a href="Daniela%20Ruah">Daniela Ruah</a>, marking the first time that the contest was presented by four hosts.
Forty-three countries participated in the contest, equalling the record of the and editions. returned after their absence from the previous edition, and for the first time since , no country withdrew.
The winner was <a href="Israel%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Israel</a> with the song "<a href="Toy%20%28song%29">Toy</a>", performed by <a href="Netta%20Barzilai">Netta</a> and written by <a href="Doron%20Medalie">Doron Medalie</a> and Stav Beger. <a href="Cyprus%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Cyprus</a>, <a href="Austria%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Austria</a>, <a href="Germany%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Germany</a> and <a href="Italy%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Italy</a> rounded out the top five, with Cyprus achieving their best result to date. Further down the table, the <a href="Czech%20Republic%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Czech Republic</a> also achieved their best result to date, finishing sixth. <a href="Portugal%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Portugal</a> finished in last place of the final, making it the third time that the host country ranked in the bottom five since . For the first time since the introduction of the semi-finals in , <a href="Azerbaijan%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="Romania%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Romania</a>, and <a href="Russia%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Russia</a> all failed to qualify for the final. Also, for the first time since , no countries of the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> region (, and Azerbaijan) participated in the final.
The EBU reported that the contest had a worldwide audience of around 186 million viewers, surpassing the 2017 edition by over 4 million.
Location.
Venue.
The <a href="Altice%20Arena">Altice Arena</a> in <a href="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> is a multi-purpose indoor arena built for the <a href="Expo%20%2798">Expo '98</a> and has a capacity of 20,000 attendees, making it the <a href="List%20of%20indoor%20arenas%20in%20Portugal">largest indoor venue in Portugal</a> and <a href="List%20of%20indoor%20arenas%20in%20Europe">among the largest in Europe</a>. It is located in the "<a href="Parque%20das%20Na%C3%A7%C3%B5es">Parque das Nações</a>" (Park of Nations) riverside district in the northeast of Lisbon, which was completely renovated to host the 1998 <a href="world%27s%20fair">world's fair</a>. It is connected by <a href="Lisbon%20Metro">metro</a> to the nearby <a href="Lisbon%20Airport">international airport</a> and by train (<a href="Gare%20do%20Oriente">Oriente Station</a>) to the rest of the country and Europe.
Bidding phase.
On the day of the Eurovision Song Contest 2017 final, it was reported that Portuguese broadcaster <a href="R%C3%A1dio%20e%20Televis%C3%A3o%20de%20Portugal">Rádio e Televisão de Portugal</a> (RTP) would accept the challenge of organising the 2018 contest in case of a victory. Following Sobral's triumph, the <a href="European%20Broadcasting%20Union">European Broadcasting Union</a> (EBU)'s Executive Supervisor for the Eurovision Song Contest, <a href="Jon%20Ola%20Sand">Jon Ola Sand</a>, issued the hosting invitation to RTP during the winner's press conference. The following day, the director-general of RTP, Nuno Artur Silva, confirmed that the broadcaster would organise the contest in 2018 and mentioned MEO Arena (later renamed <a href="Altice%20Arena">Altice Arena</a>) in <a href="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> as a likely venue to host the contest. On 15 May 2017, RTP appeared to have confirmed Lisbon as the host city, but clarified the following day that no final decision had been taken regarding both the host city and venue.
The basic requirements to select a host city were set out in a document presented by the EBU to RTP following their win in Kyiv:
Besides Lisbon, other cities signalled their interest in bidding to host the 2018 contest: <a href="Braga">Braga</a>, <a href="Espinho%2C%20Portugal">Espinho</a>, <a href="Faro%2C%20Portugal">Faro</a>, <a href="Gondomar%2C%20Portugal">Gondomar</a>, <a href="Guimar%C3%A3es">Guimarães</a>, and <a href="Santa%20Maria%20da%20Feira">Santa Maria da Feira</a>. The mayor of <a href="Porto">Porto</a>, <a href="Rui%20Moreira%20%28politician%29">Rui Moreira</a>, declared he would not be interested in "spending millions of euros" to host the contest, but he would support a bid from the <a href="Metropolitan%20Area%20of%20Porto">Metropolitan Area of Porto</a> (Espinho, Gondomar, and Santa Maria da Feira).
On 13 June 2017, RTP representatives met with the Eurovision Song Contest Reference Group at the EBU headquarters in <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a>. During the meeting, RTP officials attended a workshop covering several topics related with hosting the Eurovision Song Contest and learned from the experience of the Ukrainian broadcaster . They also had the opportunity to present their first plans for the 2018 contest, including multiple proposals for the host city and venue.
On 25 July 2017, the EBU and RTP announced that Lisbon had been selected as the host city, overcoming confirmed bids from Braga, Gondomar, Guimarães, and Santa Maria da Feira. In addition, RTP indicated the Parque das Nações, where Altice Arena is located, as the site for the shows.

Other sites.
The Eurovision Village was the official Eurovision Song Contest fan and sponsors area during the event weeks, where it was possible to watch performances by contest participants and local artists, as well as the live shows broadcast from the main venue. It was located in Lisbon's downtown <a href="Pra%C3%A7a%20do%20Com%C3%A9rcio">Praça do Comércio</a> (also called "Terreiro do Paço"), a large central square open to the <a href="Tagus%20river">Tagus river</a>.
The EuroClub was the venue for the official after-parties and private performances by contest participants. Unlike the Eurovision Village, access to the EuroClub was restricted to accredited fans, delegations, and press. It was located at the "Ministerium" club, next to the Eurovision Village.
The "Blue Carpet" event, where all the contestants and their delegations are presented before the accredited press and fans, took place on 6 May 2018 at the <a href="Museum%20of%20Art%2C%20Architecture%20and%20Technology">Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology</a> (MAAT) in Lisbon's <a href="Bel%C3%A9m%20%28Lisbon%29">Belém</a> district. This preceded the official Opening Ceremony of the 2018 contest, which took place at the nearby <a href="Electricity%20Museum">Electricity Museum</a>.
Format.
Visual design.
The theme for the contest, "All Aboard!", was unveiled on 7 November 2017 in a press conference held at the <a href="Lisbon%20Oceanarium">Lisbon Oceanarium</a>. Its visual design features oceanic motifs that allude to Lisbon and Portugal's location on the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic</a> coast and to the country's seafaring history. Alongside the main emblem, which depicts a stylised <a href="seashell">seashell</a>, twelve supplemental emblems were designed to symbolise different aspects of the marine ecosystem.
Postcards.
The postcards, filmed between March and April 2018, involved the act emerging from a door into Portugal to take part in a themed activity, such as <a href="mountain%20biking">mountain biking</a>, making a salad or "<a href="pastel%20de%20nata">pastel de nata</a>", or visiting popular attractions. The location where the activity took place was written in Portuguese at the start of the postcard. At the end of the postcard, the act posed for the camera, the slogan's hashtag appeared on the bottom corner of the screen, and song information was printed onto the country's flag. All the postcards had the same score, composed by Luis Figueredo.
Presenters.
RTP and EBU announced on 8 January 2018, that the contest would be hosted for the first time by four female presenters, consisting of RTP hosts <a href="S%C3%ADlvia%20Alberto">Sílvia Alberto</a>, <a href="Filomena%20Cautela">Filomena Cautela</a>, and <a href="Catarina%20Furtado">Catarina Furtado</a>, together with actress <a href="Daniela%20Ruah">Daniela Ruah</a>. It was the first time since that the contest did not feature a male presenter, and the second consecutive year that the presenters were all the same gender. It was confirmed on 4 May 2018 that Cautela would host the <a href="green%20room">green room</a>.
The Blue Carpet opening ceremony was hosted by actress <a href="w%3Apt%3ACl%C3%A1udia%20Semedo">Cláudia Semedo</a>, radio host Inês Lopes Gonçalves, actor/TV host <a href="w%3Apt%3APedro%20Granger">Pedro Granger</a>, and actor/director <a href="w%3Apt%3APedro%20Penim">Pedro Penim</a>. Granger and Penim moderated the press conferences, as well.
Semi-final allocation draw.
The draw to determine the allocation of the participating countries into their respective semi-finals took place on 29 January 2018 at 13:00 <a href="Central%20European%20Time">CET</a>, at <a href="Lisbon%20City%20Hall">Lisbon's City Hall</a>. The thirty-seven semi-finalists were divided over six pots, based on historical voting patterns as calculated by the contest's official televoting partner Digame. The purpose of drawing from different pots was to reduce the chance of "bloc voting" and to increase suspense in the semi-finals. The draw also determined which semi-final each of the six automatic qualifiers – host country Portugal and "<a href="Big%20Five%20%28Eurovision%29">Big Five</a>" countries , , , and the – would broadcast and vote in. The ceremony was hosted by contest presenters Sílvia Alberto and Filomena Cautela, and included the passing of the host city insignia from <a href="Vitali%20Klitschko">Vitali Klitschko</a>, mayor of <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (host city of the previous contest) to <a href="Fernando%20Medina%20%28politician%29">Fernando Medina</a>, mayor of Lisbon.
Opening and interval acts.
RTP released the first details regarding the opening and interval acts for the final on 12 March 2018. The opening act featured Portuguese <a href="fado">fado</a> singers <a href="Ana%20Moura">Ana Moura</a> and <a href="Mariza">Mariza</a> performing "Fado Loucura" and "Barco Negro", respectively, which was followed by a parade of flags introducing the 26 finalist participants, with live music by Portuguese <a href="scratching">scratching</a> duo Beatbombers. The interval acts included <a href="Salvador%20Sobral">Salvador Sobral</a>, who performed his new single "Mano a mano" and his Eurovision-winning song "<a href="Amar%20pelos%20dois">Amar pelos dois</a>" (the latter in a duet with Brazilian singer <a href="Caetano%20Veloso">Caetano Veloso</a>), and <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a> performances by <a href="Branko%20%28Jo%C3%A3o%20Barbosa%29">Branko</a> featuring <a href="Sara%20Tavares">Sara Tavares</a>, <a href="Mayra%20Andrade">Mayra Andrade</a> and Dino D'Santiago.
Participating countries.
It was initially announced on 7 November 2017 that forty-two countries would participate in the contest. confirmed their return after their absence the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202017">previous edition</a>, while 's participation was provisionally blocked by the EBU due to unpaid debts by its <a href="Macedonian%20Radio%20Television">national broadcaster</a>. However, ten days later, it was announced that Macedonia would be allowed to enter the contest, raising the number of participating countries to forty-three, equaling the highest number of participants with the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202008">2008</a> and <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202011">2011</a> editions.
Returning artists.
The contest featured two representatives who also previously performed as lead vocalists for the same countries. <a href="Alexander%20Rybak">Alexander Rybak</a> won for <a href="Norway%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Norway</a> in performing "<a href="Fairytale%20%28Alexander%20Rybak%20song%29">Fairytale</a>" (and also sang entry No. 1500) and <a href="Waylon%20%28singer%29">Waylon</a> placed second for the <a href="Netherlands%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Netherlands</a> in as part of <a href="The%20Common%20Linnets">The Common Linnets</a> performing "<a href="Calm%20After%20the%20Storm">Calm After the Storm</a>".
The contest also featured <a href="Jessica%20Mauboy">Jessica Mauboy</a>, representing <a href="Australia%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Australia</a>, after taking part in 2014 as the interval act for the second semi-final, performing "<a href="Sea%20of%20Flags">Sea of Flags</a>". In addition, the contest featured four lead singers previously participating as backing vocalists, two of them for the same countries. <a href="Lea%20Sirk">Lea Sirk</a> backed for <a href="Slovenia%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Slovenia</a> in 2014 and off-stage in , and <a href="Equinox%20%28Bulgarian%20band%29">Equinox</a> member <a href="Vladimir%20Mahailov%20%28singer%29">Vlado Mihailov</a> backed for <a href="Bulgaria%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Bulgaria</a> in 2017. <a href="Ces%C3%A1r%20Sampson">Cesár Sampson</a>, representing <a href="Austria%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Austria</a>, backed for Bulgaria in 2016 (also as a dancer) and off-stage in . <a href="SuRie">SuRie</a>, representing the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">United Kingdom</a>, backed for <a href="Belgium%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">Belgium</a> in (also as a dancer) and was the musical director again for Belgium in 2017. <a href="Sara%20Tavares">Sara Tavares</a>, who performed in the interval act, was the representative from Portugal in the <a href="1994%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest">1994 Eurovision Song Contest</a>, with the song "<a href="Chamar%20a%20m%C3%BAsica">Chamar a música</a>" reaching 8th place.
Semi-final 1.
The first semi-final took place on 8 May 2018 at 20:00 <a href="Western%20European%20Summer%20Time">WEST</a> (21:00 <a href="Central%20European%20Time">CEST</a>).
Nineteen countries participated in the first semi-final. Those countries, plus , , and the voted in this semi-final. The highlighted countries qualified for the final.
Semi-final 2.
The second semi-final took place on 10 May 2018 at 20:00 <a href="Western%20European%20Summer%20Time">WEST</a> (21:00 <a href="Central%20European%20Time">CEST</a>). Eighteen countries participated in the second semi-final. Those countries, plus , and voted in this semi-final. The highlighted countries qualified for the final.
With the approval from the Reference Group, Italy broadcast and voted in the second semi-final following a request from the broadcaster <a href="RAI">RAI</a>, as the date of the first semi-final coincided with the scheduled final of the fifth season of "<a href="The%20Voice%20of%20Italy">The Voice of Italy</a>".
Final.
The final took place on 12 May 2018 at 20:00 <a href="Western%20European%20Summer%20Time">WEST</a> (21:00 <a href="Central%20European%20Time">CEST</a>). Twenty-six countries participated in the final, with all 43 participating countries eligible to vote. The running order for the final was revealed after the press conference of the second semi-final qualifiers on 10 May.

Other countries.
Eligibility for participation in the Eurovision Song Contest requires a national broadcaster with <a href="European%20Broadcasting%20Union%23Members">active EBU membership</a>, or a special invitation from the EBU as in the case of Australia.
Broadcasts.
The European Broadcasting Union provided international live streams of both semi-finals and the grand final through their official <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> channel with no commentary. The live streams were <a href="Geo-blocking">geo-blocked</a> to viewers in Bolivia, Canada, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, United States, Uruguay and Venezuela due to "rights limitations".
Countries may add commentary from commentators working on-location or remotely at the broadcaster. Commentators can add insight to the participating entries and the provision of voting information.
Incidents.
Accusations of cultural appropriation.
Following eventual winner <a href="Netta%20Barzilai">Netta Barzilai</a>'s performance of her song "<a href="Toy%20%28song%29">Toy</a>", critics of the song accused Barzilai of <a href="Cultural%20appropriation">culturally appropriating</a> <a href="Japanese%20culture">Japanese culture</a>, with several users taking to social media to call the performance "offensive". The accusations were made after she wore a <a href="kimono">kimono</a> and <a href="Bun%20%28hairstyle%29">buns</a>, as well as <a href="Maneki-neko">Maneki-neko</a>s being shown during the performance.
The topic was debated on British morning show <a href="Good%20Morning%20Britain%20%282014%20TV%20programme%29">Good Morning Britain</a> on 14 May 2018 in response, with television presenters <a href="Trisha%20Goddard">Trisha Goddard</a> and <a href="Piers%20Morgan">Piers Morgan</a> defending Barzilai by stating that she was simply implementing elements of Japanese culture due to her own appreciation of it. English journalist <a href="Rebecca%20Reid">Rebecca Reid</a> disagreed, arguing "It's not a beautiful, loving representation of real Japanese culture. It's a costume".
Belarusian song submission.
On 10 January 2018, it had emerged on Russian social media site <a href="VK%20%28social%20networking%20website%29">VK</a> that Ukrainian singer <a href="Alekseev%20%28singer%29">Alekseev</a> had performed a <a href="Russian%20language">Russian-language</a> version of his <a href="Belarus%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">"EuroFest"</a> entry "<a href="Forever%20%28Alekseev%20song%29">Forever</a>" (as "Navsegda") in May 2017 in <a href="Stavropol">Stavropol</a> – before 1 September 2017, the submission deadline set by the EBU, potentially violating the rules of the contest. Six artists threatened to withdraw from the selection if it were allowed to compete, with Sofi Lapina actually doing so. Alekseev was ultimately allowed to compete by <a href="National%20State%20Television%20and%20Radio%20Company%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Belarus">BTRC</a> following a melodic revamp of the song, and went on to win the selection, thus earning the right to represent Belarus in the contest. However, on 23 February 2018, it was reported that the EBU had given Alekseev permission to perform his original English-language version of the song at the contest, and he would opt to sing that version of the song in May. A few weeks after that announcement, on 28 March 2018, Alekseev premiered a new version of his entry with a lighter intro and additional choir at the end of the track. He also confirmed that this version would be the one performed in Lisbon.
Czech rehearsal injuries.
On 29 April 2018, during the first rehearsal of the <a href="Czech%20Republic%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Czech Republic</a>'s performance, singer <a href="Mikolas%20Josef">Mikolas Josef</a> reportedly sustained injuries to his back while rehearsing and was subsequently taken to hospital. The singer updated his fans on Instagram, stating "I can confirm that I got injured during the rehearsal and the situation got worse after several hours. I can't even walk now. Got back from the first hospital and I am now heading to another one". He stated that he would, however, "perform no matter what". Josef performed in the first semi-final on 8 May with a slightly altered performance, owing to his injuries, and ultimately finished sixth in the final, achieving the Czech Republic's best result to date. He was also the second Czech contestant to qualify for the final, the other being <a href="Gabriela%20Gun%C4%8D%C3%ADkov%C3%A1">Gabriela Gunčíková</a> in .
China’s Mango TV censorship.
During the Chinese broadcast of the first semi-final on <a href="Mango%20TV">Mango TV</a>, the performances of <a href="Albania%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Albania</a> and <a href="Ireland%20in%20the%20Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202018">Ireland</a> were edited out of the show, along with their snippets in the recap of all 19 entries. Albania was skipped due to a ban on television performers displaying tattoos that took effect in January 2018, while Ireland was <a href="LGBT%20rights%20in%20China">censored</a> due to its representation of a homosexual couple on-stage. In addition, the <a href="Rainbow%20flag%20%28LGBT%20movement%29">LGBT flag</a> and tattoos on other performers were also blurred out from the broadcast. As a result, the EBU has terminated its partnership with Mango TV, citing that censorship "is not in line with the EBU's values of universality and inclusivity and its proud tradition of celebrating diversity through music," which led to a ban on televising the second semi-final and the grand final in the country. A spokesperson for the broadcaster's owner <a href="Hunan%20Broadcasting%20System">Hunan TV</a> said they "weren't aware" of the edits made to the programme. Ireland's representative, Ryan O'Shaughnessy told the BBC in an interview, "they haven't taken this lightly and I think it's a move in the right direction, so I'm happy about it."
United Kingdom stage invasion.
The performance of <a href="SuRie">SuRie</a>, representing the United Kingdom, in the final was disrupted by a man who rushed onto the stage and grabbed her <a href="microphone">microphone</a>, reportedly shouting "For the Nazis of the UK media, we demand freedom! War is not peace." The man, later identified as 'Dr ACactivism', a political activist from London, climbed into a camera run to get access to the stage. SuRie was able to complete her performance, and after the song the broadcast cut to an unscheduled interview in the green room. The EBU offered SuRie and her team the opportunity to perform again, but she declined. SuRie later revealed that she had suffered several bruises on her right hand. Shortly after the live broadcast on YouTube, the final was taken down and reuploaded in its entirety, with SuRie's interrupted performance edited out and substituted with her jury show performance from the previous evening. The official reupload also retains the unscheduled green room interview with the Ukrainian delegation that followed the stage invasion. The official DVD release also replaces the interrupted grand final performance with the previous evening's jury show performance. However, the British national broadcaster <a href="BBC">BBC</a> uploaded the original Saturday performance, including the stage invasion, to their YouTube channel.
Other awards.
In addition to the main winner's trophy, the <a href="Marcel%20Bezen%C3%A7on%20Awards">Marcel Bezençon Awards</a> and the <a href="Barbara%20Dex%20Award">Barbara Dex Award</a> were contested during the 2018 Eurovision Song Contest. The <a href="OGAE">OGAE</a>, "General Organisation of Eurovision Fans" voting poll also took place before the contest.
Marcel Bezençon Awards.
The <a href="Marcel%20Bezen%C3%A7on%20Awards">Marcel Bezençon Awards</a>, organised since 2002 by Sweden's then-Head of Delegation and 1992 representative <a href="Christer%20Bj%C3%B6rkman">Christer Björkman</a>, and 1984 winner <a href="Herreys">Richard Herrey</a>, honours songs in the contest's final. The awards are divided into three categories: Artistic Award, Composers Award, and Press Award. The winners were revealed shortly before the Eurovision final on 12 May.
OGAE.
<a href="OGAE">OGAE</a>, an organisation of over forty Eurovision Song Contest fan clubs across Europe and beyond, conducts an annual voting poll first held in 2002 as the Marcel Bezençon Fan Award. After all votes were cast, the top-ranked entry in the 2018 poll was also the winner of the contest, "<a href="Toy%20%28song%29">Toy</a>" performed by <a href="Netta%20Barzilai">Netta</a>; the top five results are shown below.
Barbara Dex Award.
The <a href="Barbara%20Dex%20Award">Barbara Dex Award</a> is a humorous fan award given to the worst dressed artist each year. Named after <a href="Barbara%20Dex">Belgium's representative</a> who came last in the 1993 contest, wearing her self-designed dress, the award was handed by the fansite House of Eurovision from 1997 to 2016 and is being carried out by the fansite "Songfestival.be" since 2017.
Official album.
Eurovision Song Contest: Lisbon 2018 is the official compilation album of the contest, put together by the European Broadcasting Union and released by <a href="Universal%20Music%20Group">Universal Music Group</a> <a href="Music%20download">digitally</a> on 6 April 2018 and physically on 20 April 2018. The album features all 43 participating entries, including the semi-finalists that failed to qualify for the grand final.
